attributes.title: Misinformation, Sophistication, Trust and Cognitive Abilities

q1.value: Misinformation, Sophistication, Trust and Cognitive Abilities

q2.value: Carlos Oliveira | Mathieu Turgeon | Ryan Lloyd | Alessandro Freire

q5.value: This research is supported by a Facebook Integrity Foundational Research Award

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Using a survey experiment of Brazilian WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger, Instagram, and Twitter users, we seek to determine who is most likely to be misinformed and how misinformation influences policy preferences. Specifically, we seek to evaluate if misinformed people tend to hold different public policy preferences than those who possess accurate information. We will also evaluate the extent to which misinformation is more common among those who have low levels of need for cognition, low reflective capabilities, or are strong partisans. Moreover, we will ask respondents to tell us how confident they are that the information provided is true (which it is) or false. We also propose experimentally testing how people’s policy preferences change when provided with information from a credible source. To do so, some groups will receive information, but without a credible source to support it, while others will receive the same information, but with support from a credible source. We will also evaluate the extent to which individual-level characteristics such as need for cognition, reflective capabilities, partisanship, political sophistication, and trust in traditional media moderate these effects. Our main dependent variables are support for Bolsa Família (a conditional cash transfer government program in Brazil), the use of electronic voting machines, and higher taxes on the wealthy. These topics have been highly debated in Brazil over the past few years and many Brazilians hold inaccurate beliefs about them.

q16.value: We specify the following confirmatory hypotheses: H1: Misinformed people hold different public policy preferences than those who possess accurate information. H2: Misinformed people, as compared to those who possess accurate information, tend to be more confident in their beliefs. H3: When supported by a credible information source, people are more willing to adjust their policy preference in line with the information provided. In addition to the three confirmatory hypotheses listed above, we will conduct some exploratory analyses. Specifically, we look to explore the following exploratory research questions (RQs): RQ1: Are subjects who are misinformed more likely to have low levels of need for cognition and low scores on the Cognitive Reflection Test? RQ2: Are subjects who have high levels of political sophistication, but who do not trust traditional media, more likely to be misinformed? RQ3: Are subjects who trust political news shared on social media by their friends or relatives more likely to be misinformed? RQ4: Are subjects who are high in need for cognition and have high scores on the Cognitive Reflection Test more likely to believe information when it is accompanied by a credible source? RQ5: Does partisanship have an effect on the likelihood of believing false information even in political contexts like Brazil, where political parties are not important for most voters?

q17.value: We will conduct a randomized survey experiment to evaluate the hypotheses and exploratory research questions presented above. The online survey firm Netquest will recruit approximately 8,000 adult Brazilian citizens (18+) to participate in our study. Our analyses will include all respondents and, in some cases, specific subgroups of respondents. Our main dependent variables are the support for Bolsa Família (a conditional cash transfer government program), the use of electronic voting machines, and higher taxes on the wealthy. They will be measured with the following questions: Do you think Brazil should stop using electronic voting machines in elections? (0) Yes (1) No Regarding spending on the Bolsa Família Program, what do you think the government should do? (0) Eliminate the program completely (1) Greatly reduce benefits (2) Slightly reduce benefits (3) Maintain the benefits as they are (4) Slightly increase benefits (5) Greatly increase benefits Do you believe that people with high income: (1) Should pay far lower taxes (2) Should pay slightly lower taxes (3) Already pay a fair amount of taxes (4) Should pay slightly higher taxes (5) Should pay far higher taxes Our main explanatory variable is source credibility. The experiment has two treatment groups, to which the respondents will be assigned randomly: 1) In the first treatment, participants will be assigned randomly to receive accurate information about either Bolsa Família, electronic voting machines, or taxation. They will next be asked how likely the information provided is true, followed by a question about how certain they are in their answer. Lastly, participants will be asked about their support of the said policy (Bolsa Família, electronic voting machines, or taxation ). 2) In the second treatment group, participants will receive the same questions and in the same order as in the first treatment group, but, prior to answering the policy support question, participants will receive again the accurate information provided earlier with, this time, a supporting credible source to reinforce its veracity. The complete wording of the questions can be found in the attached document. We will also administer three batteries of five questions each in order to measure need for cognition, reflection capabilities (as measured by the Cognitive Reflection Test - CRT), and political sophistication. The items from each battery will be summed and rescaled from 0 to 1. Respondents will also answer batteries of questions about their media consumption, political knowledge, and party preferences. The hypotheses and exploratory research questions will be evaluated using a series of a difference-of-means tests and regression analyses with and without interaction variables in order to account for the treatments’ main effects. Because all confirmatory hypotheses have clear expectations about the directions of the effects, we will evaluate them using a one-tailed hypothesis test at the .05 level of statistical significance.

q27.value: The survey-experiment will be conducted by the online survey firm Netquest.

attributes.title: "Seu petralha! Seu coxinha!" Political Knowledge and Mass Ideology in Brazil

q1.value: "Seu petralha! Seu coxinha!" Political Knowledge and Mass Ideology in Brazil

q2.value: Ryan Lloyd | Mathieu Turgeon | Alessandro Freire

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: One of the most consistent findings in the field of contemporary political science is that the vast majority of people know little about politics (Converse, 1964; Delli Karpini & Keeter, 1996). This lack of knowledge can affect the average citizen's ability to position herself in relation to questions that affect her and are debated in everyday politics. Another consequence of this lack of information is that voters are, in general, ambivalent about various matters and have opinions that are inconsistent over time (Zaller & Feldman, 1992). As a result, the concepts of "right" and "left" seem to make little sense for the vast majority of citizens (Converse, 1964; Oliveira & Turgeon, 2015). Some authors argue that political knowledge contributes to the structure and organization of individuals' preferences (Converse, 1964). In other words, people who are more informed about politics tend to have preferences that are more consistent with ideologies in that their attitudes about different topics are correlated with one another. Intelligence and motivation are also determinants of ideology (Luskin, 1990), as well as signals sent by political elites to voters (Layman et al., 2006). In the Brazilian case, studying the political knowledge of citizens and their ideological positioning has become more important recently because of the current political crisis. Some authors (Couto, 2014; Cavalcante, 2015) argue that Brazil has been going through a process of political radicalization, with the rise to prominence of a new right that is more conservative and radical. The intensity of partisan conflict in the streets and in Congress has particularly given rise to a perception in the media that Brazilian politics is becoming more polarized; the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff, the conviction of ex-President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, and the campaign to impeach Rousseff's successor as president, Michel Temer, have all seen the widespread mobilization of protests in the streets. However, other authors have pointed out evidence that the large majority of Brazilian voters, especially those who make up the "new middle class," have remained moderate and indifferent about many political issues (Borges & Vidigal, 2016; Rennó & Turgeon, 2016). Given these two competing backgrounds, we aim to determine how extensive polarization really is in Brazil, and what seems to be causing it. Is Brazil seeing a true ideological polarization, a deeper polarization of values (see Jacoby 2013), or simply the intensification of an affective polarization that is unrelated to other, deeper issues?

q16.value: We aim to test the hypothesis that the primary reason for the appearance of polarization in contemporary Brazil is affective, primarily a lack of trust between opposing camps. We first aim to determine, with survey data, if the ideological consistency of the Brazilian electorate has increased over the past 14 years. Have opposing camps become more radical--less centrist--in terms of ideological beliefs? We expect to find that they have not. We then aim to determine if the polarization is affective. Do opposing camps simply mistrust others, even in situations completely devoid of political ideology, if they know they support the other side? We test this with a novel experimental idea. We expect to find that this indeed is the case.

q17.value: Our first hypothesis--that perceptions of increasing polarization are unrelated to ideological radicalization--through a statistical analysis of survey data between 2002 and 2016. We will look to determine whether positions on key ideological issues--accounting for control variables--are indeed becoming further apart and more consistent among supporters of the two main political parties in Brazil, the PT and the PSDB. Our second hypothesis will be tested with an experiment using a commercially-available board game titled The Resistance: Avalon. Players are randomly (and secretly) divided into two camps in Avalon: agents of Good and Evil. Players on the side of Good must complete tasks by assembling task forces that only include players from their side. Players on the side of Evil must find a way to infiltrate these task forces by winning the trust of other players and convincing them that they are on the side of Good. The side of Good wins if they successfully complete their tasks 3 out of 5 times, while the side of Evil wins if they do not. We test our hypothesis that trust is low between PT and PSDB supporters, independent of ideology, by having subjects play this trust-based board game. Subjects will be groups composed entirely of self-identified PT supporters or self-identified PSDB supporters. Control groups play this game normally, while treatment groups will have a confederate dressed in clothing that identifies herself as being a supporter of the opposite group (PSDB for groups of PT supporters, and PT for groups of PSDB supporters). This person will undertake no other action out of the ordinary for a player of the game, and will play it normally. We will measure the number of times the confederate is included in the task forces in a given game, with the hypothesis that she will be included in significantly fewer in treatment groups than in control groups. Given that the treatment is naturally randomized in the game, the only factor affecting the inclusion of the player in the task force should be the treatment: identifying with a different political party than the other players.

attributes.title: Seeing is Believing: How Video of Police Action Aﬀects Criminal Justice Beliefs

q1.value: Seeing is Believing: How Video of Police Action Aﬀects Criminal Justice Beliefs

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: It is well established that the news media both shapes and distorts how citizens view issues of crime and justice. Media coverage in the U.S. is at best loosely related to local crime conditions (Graber, 1980; Lowry, Nio and Leitner, 2003) and often reinforces stereotypes of black criminality (Gilliam et al., 1996; Grabe and Bucy, 2009). Yet the growing availability of video footage of citizens interactions with the police, recorded by both individuals and police departments, may fundamentally change this process. By providing a more direct account of what happened, these videos may lead citizen to rely less their on preconceived notions of race and crime and make them more likely to agree on what happened and what ﬂaws exist in the current system. In this study, we explore the consequences of viewing instances of police brutality on citizens attitudes about crime, justice, and politics more generally, in two ways. First, we explore the extent to which evaluations of the same unedited police body-worn camera footage of traﬃc stop that resulted in a citizen’s complaint can be inﬂuenced by changing the justiﬁcation and result of the release of that footage. By manipulating the title of the video, participants are informed that the released footage either conﬁrmed or refuted a charge of oﬃcer misconduct. Participants responses in these conditions are compared to those in control condition in which no justiﬁcation for the release of the footage is given. Second, we explore the eﬀects of such footage when mediated through the frames of local news. Again, we compare participants evaluations of the interaction when it is framed as either conﬁrming or refuting the charge of oﬃcer misconduct to a neutral presentation of the information. We do so by manipulating the text of three written news articles, and the video of a local broadcast news clip of the event. Additionally, a ﬁnal pure control group of participants read a non-political news article about severe weather in the Midwest to allow us to assess the eﬀects of viewing this footage on broader attitudes about the criminal justice system

q16.value: This study examines three main questions. First, are interpretations of the direct footage of a citizen-police encounter provided by a body worn camera inﬂuenced by the justiﬁcation for the release of the footage–speciﬁcally whether the footage is said to conﬁrm, refute or provide no information to charge of oﬃcer behavior. Second, does the formation of beliefs about what this footage shows depend on the format in which is presented. Speciﬁcally, do patterns of interpretation diﬀer when the footage is presented directly in an unedited manner compared to when it is mediated through the format of a news broadcast. Finally, we consider how prior beliefs about the criminal justice system (CJS) may condition the impact of the justiﬁcation and format of such footage. From these questions we deﬁne a set of four possible patterns of response, detailed below, to the framing and format of the body camera footage some of which are conditional on prior CJS beliefs. Speciﬁcally, test for patterns of response consistent with no eﬀect of treatments on interpretation, eﬀects on interpretations consistent with framing, eﬀects on consistent with framing conditional on prior beliefs, and interpretations counter to framing conditional on prior beliefs. We conduct these tests ﬁrst separately by format, and then compare diﬀerences across format. We consider three main outcomes describing the legitimacy of the interaction, the behavior of the oﬃcer and the likelihood that racial bias inﬂuenced the interaction and examine how the means of these measures diﬀer across treatment conditions and subgroups. We also examine a set of secondary outcomes capturing speciﬁc emotional responses to the treatment as well as potential eﬀects on more general beliefs.

q17.value: In this study, we randomly assign several text and video treatments to subjects on Amazon's Mechanical Turk. Generally speaking, the treatments consist of both raw body camera footage and slightly altered news coverage (both televison and newspaper) of a traffic stop in Memphis, TN. We use these treatments to test the following hypotheses: Hypothesis 0. Interpretations independent of justiﬁcation for release of body camera footage Hypothesis 1. Interpretation consistent with justiﬁcation for release of body camera footage Hypothesis 2. Interpretation consistent with justiﬁcation for release of body camera footage conditional on prior beliefs Hypothesis 3. Interpretation counter to justiﬁcation for release of body camera footage conditional on prior beliefs Our general expectations with regard to these hypotheses are as follows. If police body camera footage provides a purely objective view of an interaction, than it is possible that respondents will be unmoved by the manipulation of the justiﬁcation for the footage of the release or by the format in which this footage is presented (H0). We think this is unlikely and instead expect interpretation in the conﬁrmation and refutation treatments to diﬀer from condition in which no justiﬁcation is given. As for the direction of those diﬀerences, we believe this pattern of response further depends on the format of the footage and the beliefs of those viewing it. We suspect that the “objective” nature of the unedited body camera footage will make evidence of interpretations consistent with the framing (H1, H2) more likely than interpretations counter to the framing (H3). Further it seems likely that magnitude of these eﬀects will be concentrated among respondents for whom the footage would seem to provide new information (H2). In contrast, we suspect that when this footage is presented as part of a news segment that may format activate familiar scripts about race and crime making a pattern of response of counter arguing the justiﬁcation more likely (H3). We believe prior beliefs will shape the interpretation of this footage. Such beliefs are likely intertwined with the race of our respondents. We will conduct our tests separately for groups that objective indicators such as rates of incarceration suggest are relatively advantaged (Whites and Asians) and disadvantaged (Blacks and Latinos) within the current criminal justice system. In this analysis we expect that that the relative eﬀectiveness of the justiﬁcation framing may diﬀer by group and prior beliefs. Thus, Blacks and Latinos, who are more likely to hold negative beliefs about the general fairness of the police, may be more more response responsive to the conﬁrmation framing (H1, H2) and more likely to counter argue the refutation framing (H3). In contrasts, Whites and Asians may be more likely to counter argue the conﬁrmation framing (H3) and more likely to accept the refutation framing (H1,H2).

In this analysis we expect that that the relative eﬀectiveness of the justiﬁcation framing may diﬀer by group and prior beliefs. Thus, Blacks and Latinos, who are more likely to hold negative beliefs about the general fairness of the police, may be more more response responsive to the conﬁrmation framing (H1, H2) and more likely to counter argue the refutation framing (H3). In contrasts, Whites and Asians may be more likely to counter argue the conﬁrmation framing (H3) and more likely to accept the refutation framing (H1,H2).

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Our survey has two experimental components. The first component is the random assignment of respondents into three groups, each receiving a different vignette that sets up the context of the survey, and that implicitly characterizes the moral and legal status of a war the United States is engaged in. Specifically, respondents read one of three randomly assigned primes that feature a hypothetical country “Esor,” which is accused of harboring terrorists. The government of Esor is described as unwilling to interfere with the terrorists’ activities. In the control group no information is given regarding whether the terrorists pose a threat to the United States. In treatment group one, the terrorists are described as posing an imminent threat to the United States. In treatment group two, it is specified that the terrorists do not currently pose a threat against the United States. Respondents across all three groups are then asked to imagine that the leadership of the United States has decided to wage war against Esor. The two treatments track the difference between a morally and legally prima facie permissible (treatment one) and an impermissible (treatment two) resort to armed force. The second experimental component features a conjoint survey design, where respondents are asked to indicate their preferences for particular war strategies and individual attacks. Each respondent is presented with 5 pairs of war strategies and 5 pairs of individual attacks. Whether respondents are first presented with individual attacks or strategies is randomly assigned. In the first (second) conjoint set-up, respondents are asked to choose between two attacks with randomly varying attributes. They are also asked to separately rate their support for launching each attack on a scale of 1 to 7. The attributes of the targets vary so as to reflect the conformity of an attack with various moral and legal principles. The impact of the individual attributes on respondents' choices and ratings will be indicative of the extent to which their attitudes track these principles. In the second (first) conjoint set-up, respondents are asked to choose between and rate their support for two strategies for waging the hypothetical war against Esor. The strategies have randomly varying attributes which reflect different costs associated with waging war. The impact of the individual attributes on respondents' choices and ratings will be indicative of how respondents trade-off concern for these costs and whether/how such concerns influence war support. As this study breaks new ground, we test competing hypotheses to elucidate whether respondents' attitudes track legal categories, moral principles, instrumental considerations or the findings of existing studies regarding attitudes towards military casualties. Unless otherwise specified, all hypotheses below refer to both the choice outcome and the rating outcome as dependent variables.

q16.value: H1a: Subjects that receive the “imminent threat” treatment are more supportive of the war than subjects in the control group that do not receive that treatment. H1b: Subjects that receive the “no imminent threat” treatment are less supportive of the war than subjects in the control group that do not receive that treatment. H2a: Subjects that receive the “imminent threat” treatment have a higher threat perception than subjects in the control group that do not receive that treatment. H2b: Subjects that receive the “no imminent threat” treatment have a lower threat perception than subjects in the control group that do not receive that treatment. H3a: Subjects that receive the “imminent threat” treatment have a stronger tendency to support individual attacks than those in the control group that do not receive this treatment. H3b: Subjects that receive the “no imminent threat” treatment have a weaker tendency to support individual attacks than those in the control group that do not receive this treatment. H4: Respondents prefer attacks on military targets to attacks on political targets. H5a: Respondents prefer attacks in which the expected civilian casualties contribute more to Esor’s war. H5b: The effect hypothesized in H5a depends on whether a war pursues a just aim. It should therefore only obtain for respondents that received the “imminent threat” treatment. H6: Respondents prefer attacks with lower numbers of expected civilian casualties. H7: The negative effect of the expected number of civilian casualties is stronger the lower the contribution of the attack to victory. H8a: The negative effect of the expected number of civilian casualties is stronger the less civilians contribute to the war. H8b: The effect hypothesized in H8a depends on whether a war pursues a just aim. It should hence only obtain for respondents that received the “imminent threat” treatment and who thus face an unjust opponent. H9: Respondents prefer attacks with a higher contribution to victory. H10: The type of target should have a larger effect than the other presented attributes H11a: The liability of the civilians (expressed here in terms of a contribution to the war) should have a larger effect than the other presented attributes. H11b: The effect hypothesized in H11a depends on whether a war pursues a just aim. It should hence only obtain for respondents that received the “imminent threat” treatment and who thus face an unjust opponent. H12: The contribution of an attack to victory should have a larger effect than the other presented attributes. H13a: Subjects that receive the “imminent threat” treatment are more supportive of strategies for fighting the war (rating outcome) than subjects in the control group that do not receive that treatment. H13b: Subjects that receive the “no imminent threat” treatment are less supportive of strategies for fighting the war (rating outcome) than subjects in the control group that do not receive that treatment. H14a: Respondents prefer strategies with lower numbers of projected casualties among civilians. H14b: The effect described in H14a is weaker for subjects that receive the “imminent threat” treatment than for subjects in the control group. H14c: The effect described in H14a is stronger for subjects that receive the “no imminent threat” treatment than for subjects in the control group. H15: Respondents prefer strategies with a higher chance of victory. H16: Respondents prefer strategies with lower monetary costs. H17: Respondents prefer strategies with lower numbers of projected casualties among U.S. troops. H18: Civilian casualties have a stronger negative effect on war support than other attributes. H19: The projected likelihood of success has a stronger positive effect on war support than other attributes H20: U.S. casualties have a stronger negative effect on war support than other attributes. H21: The effect described in H20 might be weaker the higher the likelihood of success of a war.

q17.value: Hypotheses on the effects of individual attack/strategy attributes are tested by estimating the "average marginal component effect" (AMCE), i.e., the marginal effect of each attribute averaged over the joint distribution of the other attributes (Hainmueller et al. 2014). Hypotheses that imply that an effect varies between different prime groups, and/or that the effect of particular strategy/attack attributes depends on values of other attributes, are tested with interactions. The possibility of heterogeneous treatment effects with respect to respondents' background characteristics is explored with interactions as well. We estimate the distinct interaction quantities proposed by Egami and Imai (2016+) and Hainmueller et al. (2014).

attributes.title: Building Judicial Legitimacy or Inviting Institutional Backlash? Kenya’s Supreme Court and the Invalidation of the 2017 Presidential Election

q1.value: Building Judicial Legitimacy or Inviting Institutional Backlash? Kenya’s Supreme Court and the Invalidation of the 2017 Presidential Election

q2.value: Eric Kramon | Brandon Bartels | Jeremy Horowitz

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: On September 1, 2017, the Supreme Court of Kenya, in a historic 4-2 ruling, annulled the results of the August 8, 2017 presidential election won by incumbent President Uhuru Kenyatta over Raila Odinga (54%-45%). Declaring that election irregularities violated Kenya’s Constitution, the Court directed the country’s electoral authority to hold a new election within 60 days. In a country without a history of robust judicial power or strong democratic norms (Mueller 2008; Mutua 2001), this episode presents a crucial test of the Kenyan Supreme Court’s legitimacy, or rightful authority to render declarative rulings for the polity (e.g., Gibson and Nelson 2014; Tyler 2006a). Scholars and experts believe that granting high courts robust constitutional authority is necessary for enforcing the rule of law, maintaining judicial independence, and ensuring democratic governance (e.g., Baird 2001; Gibson, Caldeira, and Baird 1998; Ginsburg 2003; Widner 2001). A strong high court depends on widespread subscription to judicial supremacy—the principle that the court has the final word on constitutional meaning for everyone in the country (Friedman 1998; Friedman and Delaney 2011; Whittington 2007). Because high courts possess “neither the purse nor the sword,” their legitimacy—rooted in judicial supremacy—serves as an important mechanism for enforcing their rulings. Thus, how the public and elites respond to landmark assertions of judicial power is important for the rule of law and democratic governance. This project asks three questions: (1) How do Kenyan citizens evaluate their Supreme Court, in terms of the legitimacy of the Court and its ruling, its authority vis-a-vis the other branches and the public, and whether it is perceived as impartial and legalistic versus politicized and biased? (2) Which theoretical model—a procedural fairness model versus an “ethnopartisan bias” model—best explains how citizens grant legitimacy to the Court in response to this monumental ruling? (3) How do attitudes about judicial legitimacy change over time as the consequences of court decisions are revealed, in this case, after the new election?

q16.value: Hypotheses for Question 1 will be tested observationally. We test four sets of hypotheses. Process-based Hypotheses (H1): H1A: Perceptions of the court’s procedural fairness will enhance judgments of Supreme Court legitimacy; H1B: Subscription to democratic values will enhance judgments of Supreme Court legitimacy; H1C: Political knowledge and engagement will enhance judgments of Supreme Court legitimacy. Enthnopartisan Bias Hypotheses (H2): H2A: Citizens with ethnopartisan attachment to Kenyatta will ascribe lower legitimacy to the Court than other citizens; H2B: Citizens with ethnopartisan attachment to Odinga will ascribe higher legitimacy to the Court than other citizens. Process-based Attenuation Hypotheses (H3): H3: Perceptions of procedural fairness, democratic values, and political knowledge/engagement will attenuate the impact of ethnopartisan bias on legitimacy (rooted in procedural justice and positivity theory). Outcome-based Enhancement Hypothesis (H4): H4: Political knowledge/engagement will enhance the impact of ethnopartisan bias on legitimacy (rooted in motivated reasoning theory and an outcome-based approach). Hypotheses for Question 2 will be tested experimentally using a survey experiment. We test three sets of hypotheses. Process-based Hypothesis (H5): H5: Priming the procedural fairness of the Court’s ruling will enhance legitimacy. Enthnopartisan Cues Hypotheses (H6): H6A: Elite cues endorsing the ruling will enhance legitimacy; H6B: Elite cues opposing the ruling will reduce legitimacy; H6C: Elite cues endorsing the ruling (by Kenyatta) will attenuate the impact of ethnopartisan attachment on legitimacy; a Kenyatta endorsement will increase legitimacy among his supporters and have less or no effect on others; H6D: Elite cues opposing the ruling (by Kenyatta) will enhance the impact of ethnopartisan attachment on legitimacy; a Kenyatta endorsement will decrease legitimacy among his supporters and either increase legitimacy (via backlash) or have no effect on others. Process-based Attenuation (H7): H7A: Primes about procedural fairness will attenuate the impact of ethnopartisan attachment on court legitimacy; H7B: Primes about procedural fairness will attenuate the impact of elite cues on court legitimacy; H7C: Elite cues endorsing the ruling (by Kenyatta) will increase the attenuating role of procedural fairness hypothesized in H7A; H7D: Elite cues opposing the ruling (by Kenyatta) will diminish the attenuating role of procedural fairness hypothesized in H7A. We will also examine a set of heterogeneous treatment effects that focuses on the moderating role of pre-existing Political Knowledge and Engagement. It is possible that the impact of our treatments will vary based on the strength of participants’ prior beliefs. To the extent that politically knowledgeable and engaged subjects have strong priors on the outcomes, we would expect the effects to be smaller among knowledgeable and engaged citizens. On the other hand, there is also the potential for greater backlash among those with strong prior beliefs and who receive a treatment that runs in opposition to their prior. Consistent with motivated reasoning theory, these more politically knowledgeable respondents could be exhibit backlash against the primes.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, we will field a two-wave national panel survey that will include observational questions and a survey experiment. Wave 1 of the survey will be fielded before the next election on October 26, 2017. Wave 2 will be fielded after that election. We will interview 2,500 respondents in Wave 1.

attributes.title: Crafting Payoffs: Behavioral Foundations of China’s Economic Inducements in the Philippines

q1.value: Crafting Payoffs: Behavioral Foundations of China’s Economic Inducements in the Philippines

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Economic statecraft – the use of economic tools to pursue political goals – has been an important part of China’s foreign policy. However, both large-N analyses and case studies have produced conflicting conclusions on whether economic statecraft is effective. China has often used economic inducements in an effort to influence the policies of target countries, but this has had varying degrees of success. What characteristics of economic statecraft strategies allow or impede political effectiveness? Specifically, what kind of effects do economic inducements have on public opinion in the target country? Conducting a survey experiment in the Philippines, I investigate how different types of economic inducements from China influence public opinion. Based on my previous fieldwork and case study research, I categorize variation in inducement strategies along two main dimensions: (i) conditionality – whether the provided inducements are linked to certain political demands from China; and (ii) beneficiaries – whether the inducement benefits are targeted to a small group of political and business elites, or to the broader population. I investigate whether Chinese inducement strategies that are more conditional or that benefit a small group of political and business elites are more likely to produce public backlash. This backlash could manifest in one or both of two ways: public attitudes toward China and Chinese policies; and public attitudes toward the target country government. This backfiring effect reduces the political effectiveness of China’s economic inducements.

q16.value: I test two sets of hypotheses on when economic inducements create a backfire effect: (H1a) Imposing conditionality on economic inducements worsens public attitudes toward China. (H1b) Imposing conditionality on economic inducements decreases approval ratings of the target government and makes voters more likely to vote against political incumbents. (H2a) Targeting the economic benefits of inducements to a small group of political and business elites worsens public attitudes toward China. (H2b) Targeting the economic benefits of inducements to a small group of political and business elites decreases approval ratings of the target government and makes voters more likely to vote against political incumbents.

q17.value: I test my hypotheses in the Philippines, which is an important case study. The Philippines is an active dispute claimant against China in the South China Sea. Beijing’s use of economic inducements has also been a salient debate for the public as well as political leaders. While the online population in the Philippines will tend to be disproportionately urban and middle-class, this represents an important and vocal constituency in Philippine electoral politics. The sample of N=600 will be drawn using a Qualtrics online panel. Qualtrics panel providers email respondents with a link to take the survey. Aside from age restrictions (over 18) and consent to participate, no other eligibility based on demographic factors is considered.

attributes.title: Voting intentions versus participation in voting

q1.value: Voting intentions versus participation in voting

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: When scholars analyze voting behavior at the individual level, they usually have to rely on self-reports of past and intended voting. However, it is widely known that these responses suffer from recall-bias: that respondents over-report their past votes, and overstate the strength of their voting intentions. But by how much? We use a unique dataset to answer this question. We conducted a large-scale (n=2,500) survey in Armenia prior to a crucial parliamentary election. This together with unique policy of obligatory publishing of the names of all voters, allows us to answer these fundamental questions.

q16.value: 1. Do people over-report voting intentions and past voting behavior. If yes, is there a difference between the misreporting of voting intentions and past behavior? 2. Is “do not know” option in the question about voting intentions is an excuse to not the say “known “no”? We hypothesize that the share of nonvoters among those who answered “do not know” will be as high as the share of nonvoter who answers “not going to vote”.

q17.value: We can answer Question 1 by analyzing the distribution of the misreporting variables, and test the second part of question 1 using simple proportion tests of, and Fisher exact tests, with treatment being the year of elections. The hypothesis in question 2 is also directly tested through Fisher tests of participation_2018 with treatment variable being the answer “no” or “do not know” in voting_intentions survey question.

registration_responses.q16: 1. Do people over-report voting intentions and past voting behavior. If yes, is there a difference between the misreporting of voting intentions and past behavior? 2. Is “do not know” option in the question about voting intentions is an excuse to not the say “known “no”? We hypothesize that the share of nonvoters among those who answered “do not know” will be as high as the share of nonvoter who answers “not going to vote”.
registration_responses.q17: We can answer Question 1 by analyzing the distribution of the misreporting variables, and test the second part of question 1 using simple proportion tests of, and Fisher exact tests, with treatment being the year of elections. The hypothesis in question 2 is also directly tested through Fisher tests of participation_2018 with treatment variable being the answer “no” or “do not know” in voting_intentions survey question.

attributes.title: Gendered Distribution of Impact Evidence to Policy Makers

q1.value: Gendered Distribution of Impact Evidence to Policy Makers

q2.value: Rachel E. A. Finlayson | Daniel Nielson

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Description of research question and justification for undertaking the trial, including summary of relevant studies (published and unpublished) examining benefits and harms for each intervention. Gendered Distribution of Impact Evidence to Policy Makers seeks to understand the effect of gender, if any, in positive responses to information about impact evidence in development. This project asks the question: "Do females receive more positive responses when soliciting meetings to introduce the Impact Evidence website?" To address the gap between policy makers and research, researchers at Brigham Young University (BYU) – a member of the AidData Center for Development Policy consortium of the College of William and Mary, Brigham Young University, University of Texas-Austin, Development Gateway, and Esri – have designed an evaluation to better understand the conditions under which impact evaluation results impact policy decisions. We wish to identify the most effective way to encourage policymakers to use a new website featuring the results of impact evaluations that may be relevant for policy. The website will provide easily accessible information about the real-world impacts of different types of development policies in diverse sectors and countries. The information is harvested from about 500 high-quality scholarly impact evaluations. We will promote the website through office visits in select countries. This project focuses on the latter step in the process- office visits. All of our subjects are elected or appointed public officials, and we believe this project will provide valuable information to the development community in identifying what sorts of information and presentation is most helpful to potential users.

q16.value: We predict that as local and western men and women contact policymakers and attempt to schedule appointments to demonstrate the Impact Evidence website, western women have more favorable responses than western men, local men will have more favorable responses than local women, and westerners have more favorable response than locals. The rationale for this is that women in both US and Tanzanian societies are socialized to be more community-oriented and have enhanced communication skills. US women have the added advantage of being perceived as powerful and well connected due to their nationality. However, in Tanzania, women make up merely a third of government representatives, suggesting that women may be perceived as having less authority. As a result, we predict that women as a group had more success in scheduling and holding meetings with Tanzanian policymakers, that western women received more positive responses than local women, but that local men fared better than local women. H1: Women received more positive responses than men. H2: Western women received more positive responses than local women. H3: Women received more positive responses than men when approaching men. H4: Women received more positive responses than men when approaching women. H5: Local women received more positive responses than western women when approaching women. H6: Western women received more positive responses than local women when approaching men. H7: Women trained more individuals than men. H8: Western women trained more individuals than local women. H9: Local women received fewer positive responses than local men.

q17.value: We will test these hypotheses by running statistical tests on the data we gathered and controlling for country of origin, gender of enumerator, and gender of policymaker. We will test for statistically significant differences in positive responses among local men, local women, western men, and western women. We define statistical significance to be a p-value of 0.05.

q2.value: Mathieu Turgeon | Alessandro Freire | Ryan Lloyd | Carlos Oliveira

q5.value: This research is supported by a Facebook Integrity Foundational Research Award.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We use a survey experiment for WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger, Instagram, and Twitter users to determine who is most vulnerable to misinformation/fake news circulated on these social media platforms and whether (and how) corrections to misinformation influence political preferences in Brazil. Specifically, we look at the nature of fake news by focusing on whether or not the false information it conveys directly threatens one’s own self-interest. In other words, if someone is exposed to false information that could potentially put her self-interest (such as her income or property) at risk, will that person be more likely to change her political preferences? Past research on political attitudes show that self-interest matters when the gains or losses in a policy are clear and tangible and when respondents are primed to think about the potential gains or losses of the policy in question (Chong et al. 2001). Furthermore, we want to see if a correction undo fake news’ effect, even among those whose self-interest is most threatened by the misinformation. We also will evaluate if anxiety and fear are triggered by interest-threatening misinformation and if they mediate the misinformation’s effect on political preferences. Finally, we want to see if these effects are moderated by other individual-level characteristics, such as political sophistication, capability of reflection, and predisposition to engage in activities that require higher-level thinking. Our main outcome is support for pension reform, as measured in a survey. We have two different types of interventions. One is the provision of false information (presumably circulating on social media platforms) about possible consequences if pension reform fails. The second intervention is identical to the first one, but with a correction stating that the information is not true. These two interventions are implemented as text embedded in a survey question. Our design proposes three such consequences for a total of six treatment groups (one for each of the three possible consequences both with and without the correction) and one control group, all randomly assigned. The consequences are designed to threaten the self-interest of specific groups of the Brazilian population.

q16.value: We specify the following confirmatory hypotheses: H1: False information increases support for pension reform among treatment respondents whose interests are most at stake should pension reform fail (as primed by the false information presumably circulating on social media platforms), as compared to control group subjects who share the same interests but that have not received the false information threatening their self-interest. H2: False information, even when corrected, increases support for pension reform among treatment respondents whose interests are most at stake should pension reform fail (as primed by the false information presumably circulating on social media platforms), as compared to control group subjects who share the same interests but that have not received the false information threatening their self-interest. H3: The effect of false information on support for pension reform among treatment respondents whose interests are most at stake in the event should pension reform fail (as primed by the false information presumably circulating on social media platforms) is strongest among subjects high in need for cognition. H4: The effect of false information in increasing support for pension reform among treatment respondents whose interests are most at stake should pension reform fail (as primed by the false information presumably circulating on social media platforms) is strongest among subjects with high capabilities of reflection. H5: The effect of false information in increasing support for pension reform among treatment respondents whose interests are most at stake should pension reform fail (as primed by the false information presumably circulating on social media platforms) is strongest among politically sophisticated subjects. H6: The effect of false information, when corrected, in increasing support for pension reform among treatment respondents whose interests are most at stake should pension reform fail (as primed by the false information presumably circulating on social media platforms) is weakest among subjects high in need for cognition. H7: The effect of false information, when corrected, in increasing support for pension reform among treatment respondents whose interests are most at stake should pension reform fail (as primed by the false information presumably circulating on social media platforms) is weakest among subjects with high capabilities of reflection. H8: The effect of false information, when corrected, in increasing support for pension reform among treatment respondents whose interests are most at stake should pension reform fail (as primed by the false information presumably circulating on social media platforms) is weakest among politically sophisticated subjects. In addition to the eight confirmatory hypotheses listed above, we will conduct some exploratory analyses. Specifically, we look to explore the following exploratory research questions (RQs): RQ1: Are subjects whose self-interest is most threatened by the false information more likely to believe that the (false) information is true? RQ2: Are subjects whose self-interest is most threatened by the false information more likely to share the (false) information? RQ3: Does false information (presumably circulating on social media platforms) increase anxiety among subjects whose self-interest is most threatened? RQ4: Does false information (presumably circulating on social media platforms) increase fear among subjects whose self-interest is most threatened? RQ5: Does need for cognition, capability of reflection, or knowledge of politics matter most for explaining people’s resistance to false information? RQ6: Does need for cognition, capability of reflection, or knowledge of politics matter most for explaining people’s acceptance of corrections of false information?

q17.value: We will conduct a randomized survey experiment to evaluate the hypotheses and exploratory research questions presented above. The online survey firm Netquest will recruit about 8,000 adult Brazilian citizens (18+) to participate in our study. Our analyses will include all respondents and, in some cases, specific subgroups of respondents. Our main outcome variable is support for pension reform and will be measured with the following question: Regarding the pension reform presented by the Bolsonaro administration, you would say that you: 1. Completely disagree 2. Partially disagree 3. Neither agree nor disagree 4. Agree partially 5. Completely agree Our explanatory variables are assignments to varying treatments. They are of two types: 1) some respondents will be randomly assigned to be informed about one of three possible (false) consequences should pension reform fail. The possible consequences are: 1) a decrease in the benefits paid to Bolsa Familia (a social welfare program) recipients; 2) an increase in income taxes (for those who pay income taxes); and, 3) an increase in the tax on gasoline. 2) some respondents will be randomly assigned to receive the same three possible (false) consequences, but, followed with a correction indicating that the information has been checked and declared false. Some respondents will also be randomly assigned to a control group where they will only receive the outcome variable question, as presented above. The complete wording of the six treatment groups can be found in the attached document, together with the questions asking whether treatment group respondents believe that the (false) information presumably circulating on social media platforms is true, how likely they would be to circulate the (false) information were they to receive it, and how much the (false) information makes them anxious and scared. Respondents will also be asked about whether they (or someone in their family) were a recipient of Bolsa Familia, pay income taxes, and own a car or motorcycle. These variables will be used to indicate if the respondent’s self-interest is at stake. We will also administer three batteries of five questions to measure need for cognition, capabilities of reflection (as measured by RCT), and political sophistication. The items from each battery will be summed and rescaled to range from 0 to 1. The hypotheses and exploratory research questions will be evaluated using a series of difference-of-means tests and regression analyses (OLS) with and without interaction variables to account for the treatments’ main effects, as well as the moderating effects of need for cognition, capability of reflection, and political sophistication. Because all confirmatory hypotheses have clear expectations about the direction of the effects, we will evaluate them using a one-tailed hypothesis test at the .05 level of statistical significance.

q27.value: The survey-experiment will be conducted by the online survey firm Netquest.
